Reviews.Title: Panasonic put a lock on the firmware: BUT IT HAS BEEN CRACKED
Reviews.Author: David Siegfried
Reviews.Content: Like many others, I had read all the buzz on the web about the third-party firmware update created by "Tester 13" for this camera. The Tester 13 firmware code opens up new possibilities for independent filmmakers and video artists such as myself. For one, it allows the camera to output in its native 24p frame rate in 1920 x 1080 HD resolution instead of the 60i "wrapper" that makes areas of the exposure look like "mud". 24p is also the same rate as traditional 35mm movie film, and it's what gives video that "cinematography look". The Tester 13 firmware also allowed quite a few other modifications that got independent cinematographers excited. I won't get into them all here, the info is available on the web. If you have heard of the Magic Lantern software for the Canon 5D Mark II, then the Tester 13 software is the equivalent for the GH1.The Tester 13 open source firmware is based on v. 1.32 of the Panasonic firmware. This is the only version that is currently available for download at the Panasonic website. However, around June 2010 Panasonic started shipping units with a new firmware installed, v 1.34. THIS 1.34 FIRMWARE VERSION IS LOCKED AND PANASONIC HAS NOT RELEASED IT TO THE PUBLIC DESPITE NUMEROUS REQUESTS FROM CAMERA OWNERS. There are no extra features in this firmware except the "feature" that it prevents any firmware modifications from third party developers.I didn't find out about this until I bought THREE of these units, intending to apply the Tester 13 firmware to achieve the enhanced video output that I wanted. It was only after I was NOT able to do the firmware update that I discovered the bad news buried in the DVXUSER forum that Panasonic has locked the firmware on new GF1 and GH1 cameras and not released the new firmware, in order to prevent third party open source developers from modifying it.Why they would do this seems like a shot in the foot, because there is a great demand among independent filmmakers to use this camera strictly for its movie-making abilities with the Tester 13 "hack". Imagine my great disappointment, anger and dismay after buying three of these cameras and then finding out that they all had the "locked" firmware. The 24p output was why I bought them and I'm going to have to return them. >:-(I realize this is a good still camera, and a good movie camera for consumers even without the modifications. But the 24p native output of the sensor has been cobbled by Panasonic by forcing the output into a 60i "wrapper" which essentially creates what videographers call "mud" - crappy, noisy, undefined, compressed, unusable footage. Presumably the only reason they put a lock on is because they are releasing the new GH2 with native 24p in December 2010 and they don't want free the third party "hack" competing with their own product. But shame on them for stifling the creativity of their customer base -- I say boycott Panasonic until they unlock this camera or release the 1.34 firmware to the public!!If and when they do unlock it, I will revise my rating.IMPORTANT UPDATE: Tester 13 cracked the firmware on the "locked" GH1. This camera is fully hackable now !! I'm upgrading my rating to two stars because it was done in SPITE of Panasonic's efforts to stop it.By the way, the "hack" is not all it's "cracked" up to be. Yes, it allows much faster bitrates and native 24p, but it does it at the cost of reliablity. The hacked cameras are prone to sudden stopping and loss of data. Worse, the hacked camera doesn't span files, it stops recording after reaching the 4gb file limit (about 15 minutes). I have given up on the GH1 and moved on to the GH2. It does better bitrate and native 24p out of the box. The GH1 turned out to be a wild goose chase for me.

Reviews.Title: Top 5 suggestions for new GH1 users
Reviews.Author: superifico
Reviews.Content: I've used this camera for about 9 months now. I could talk endlessly about pros & cons, but they're mostly been covered in other reviews. Instead, here are my top suggestions to any new GH1 user:1) Remove the neck-strap links from the lugs on the camera body. They make noise (bad for video), plus they torque the lugs, which (according to other reviews) has caused some lug failures. You can replace them with small zip-ties, or small finger-loops of 1/8" paracord (my preference), or use a wrist strap.2) Avoid the "for dummies" iA mode, especially if you want to shoot anything indoors. iA mode does OK outdoors in the sun, but indoors, it always chooses too low an ISO, giving you blurry or underexposed photos. Forget it. You can still configure your camera for friends/family to just "point & shoot". Just set the dial to "P", and set the ISO yourself. 100 for bright outdoors, 800 for natural light indoors, is a good rule of thumb. Also set the White Balance manually, if you want to avoid some post-processing.3) If you want to play with shallow DoF/bokeh, or take great portaits in general, buy a $30 adapter for Canon FD lenses, and buy a Canon FD 50mm/f1.4 lens on ebay for $50-100. Unbelievable value. Or, you could spend 10 times that much for a "modern" portrait lens with auto-everything, and hope the camera is smarter than you...good luck. :)4) If you want to shoot indoors without flash, buy the Lumix 20mm/f1.7 pancake lens. The kit lens is simply not fast enough (f4-f5.6) for shooting decent quality indoors photos in most cases.5) If you plan to edit your videos, shoot MJPEG. The ONLY reason I can see to use AVCHD is the consumer-convenience of burning home videos directly to blu-ray. The AVCHD 1080i resolution is not a benefit, when the quality sucks compared to MJPEG 720p. YMMV.----------+4 stars for the shockingly good sensor, kit lens, and EVF; size & weight; build quality; video modes; articulating LCD; ability to use practically any lens you can get your hands on-1 star for the poor iA mode; lack of higher quality video settings without hacking; poorly written manual; minor UI shortcomingsCompared against current Canon and Nikon offerings, this camera should get 6 stars. But I had to complain about something. :)Oh also...if you plan to shoot primarily indoors or other low-light scenes, consider the new GH2 instead. It has a better sensor for low light/high ISO. But the GH1 has a better overall quality sensor, plus a much much better kit lens.

Reviews.Title: A note about cost ...
Reviews.Author: zzmahn
Reviews.Content: Before I get into the title of my review, let me give a little background. Before I got into the "wife and kids" phase of my life, I was heavily into 35 mm photography. My current 35mm system is a Nikon 8008 with a full complement of lens that I rarely get out due to its bulk and weight. In line with the phrase, "the best camera is the one you have with you," I finally succumbed to an weatherproof P&S; (point and shoot) that we took along with us for family events, vacations, ect. When this camera died on our last vacation, I decided (actually my wife) to investigate higher end digital cameras.My initial focus was upon a DSLR (digital single lens reflex) to replace my Nikon 8008 (i.e., I could use my old lens). In researching cameras to death (my wife was getting irritated at my single mindedness although she knew this when she married an engineer :), I came upon this interesting four thirds format. Many reviews are out there that explain the details, however, the following points are the ones that had me hooked:- No mirrors (as with DSLRs) means inherently smaller camera size for both the camera body.- The four thirds system offers several distinct advantages in also being able to shoot live video over a DLSR.- Soundless zooming and focusing using a image stabilized interchangeable lens (great for both camera and video applications).- Sensor size is roughly 6 times bigger than a typical P&S; and 22 times bigger than a typical video camcorder.So interestingly, my pursuit of a DSLR resulted in finding a hybrid system that has the best of both worlds - a camera and camcorder in one small package. Now on to the economics of what I eventually decided. I was torn between the Lumix GF1, GH1, and the soon to be released GH2. I was leaning heavily to wait for the GH2 (Panasonic Lumix DMC-GH2 16.05 MP Live MOS Interchangeable Lens Camera with 3-inch Free-Angle Touch Screen LCD and 14-140mm HD Hybrid Lens (Black)). This camera had a big sensor and the coveted 14-140 lens (roughly equivalent to a DSLR 28-280 lens). I also knew that I wanted the 20 mm, f/1.7 lens (Panasonic LUMIX G 20mm f/1.7 Aspherical Pancake Lens for Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Cameras)for shooting in low light conditions. Total cost of planned purchase $1835.However, I was curious about the pricing trends of both the GF1 and GH1 and so I looked them both up on NexTag. As is the case with any new product, being the first in line means you pay top dollar. Buying the old version before the introduction of the new version is a definite bonus for the financially frugal. So, I ended up buying the GF1 with the 20 mm lens (Panasonic Lumix DMC-GF1 12.1MP Micro Four-Thirds Interchangeable Lens Digital Camera with LUMIX G 20mm f/1.7 Aspherical Lens) and the GH1 with the 14-140 mm zoom lens (Panasonic DMC-GH1K 12.1MP Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Camera with 1080p HD Video). In so doing, I got two cameras (each with their distinct purpose), two lenses, and two batteries for $1683.Hope this helps you in your decision process. I've been putting both cameras through their paces and have been very impressed with their performance and portability. I am so glad that I took the plunge am enjoying both the art of photography and the new-found art of videography in one elegant package.

Reviews.Title: lovely camera
Reviews.Author: K. Strand
Reviews.Content: I ordered this particular camera for the new micro four thirds format and also thanks to many reviews citing Lumix as the the industry standard in this new format. This is a lovely camera, especially for its performance in low light situations. I am finding it less compact than I had hoped, not that much smaller than a standard DSLR. However, even a small size difference helps when travelling, and I really enjoyed shooting with this camera on my recent trip to Italy.

Reviews.Title: Very pleased
Reviews.Author: J. Pinegar
Reviews.Content: Before this camera I have mainly used just point and shoots and was looking for a step up. This camera is pretty much everything I hoped for. With the single exception that the 1080p HD video is only good in some situations. At recording at 17 mbps it too little information to record lots of quick movements in full detail. Thus in those situations you get some blurring. For what's ever it is worth, I have read rumors that it will be upgraded to 24 or 28 mbps in a future firmware update. So this issue could go away in the future. It still does excellent video in all situations at 720p.  As far as pictures go, the camera is very intuitive as to how to take good pictures with its many presets, but it also give you lots of room to take greater and greater control as your photography knowledge increases. I would highly recommend reading all of the owners manual if you want to get the most out of this camera. And if you are new to the more advanced world of photography, once again after you have had some time to experiment with it. Handling some of my friends DSLR's this camera is indeed much lighter and diminutive, but if you are used to a point and shoot there is certainly some added bulk. If you do also opt to also get the "Panasonic LUMIX G 20mm f/1.7 A-spherical Pancake Lens", that tiny yet high quality lens turns the camera into something that you can easily fit in a jacket or cargo shorts pocket. Keep in mind that the camera that just blows point and shoots out of the water in terms of picture and video quality. The pancake lens will also allow you to take better shots and video with low light, especially without a tripod. The kit lens only goes to f/4 in wide and f/5.3 in telephoto. Just the same the kit lens is very capable and better over all for video (basically silent AF(auto focus), and good optical zoom range), but weights more then the camera body. Which should tell you something about how light the camera itself is given its capabilities. The camera and kit lens together weight about 2lbs. Which is at least a third less to anything you will find with a DSLR and similar wide/telephoto lens combination. And the DSLR and lens won't AF while filming 1080p or 720p like this camera and lens combo will.  I bought a scandisk 16gig class 10 card along with the camera and have no problem with buffering in any of the shooting or video situations. Anything slower then a Class 10 and you probably will run into issues if you plan on shooting 1080p video with this camera.A few other quick mentions:  *LCD screen flips out and reverse so you can see it on the lens side too (good for when using the timer function)  *TV play back features for slide shows and videos are good (include the the box is a WVGA cable, but not an HDMI cable)  *Manual said that battery was good for about 320 shots. I got 480 and I still used AFSAll in all I would recommend this camera and kit lens to anyone who wants a highly capable camera in a diminutive package.

Reviews.Title: picture quality is good but build quality is really bad

Reviews.Content: I have being using this camera for over a year and use it almost everyday.The body size is good and portable. Reviews.Title: The best 4/3rds or micro 4/3rds has to offer
Reviews.Author: Noirist
Reviews.Content: I've owned my GH1 for nine months now, and used it to take tens of thousands of pictures and hundreds of hours of video. Normally I wouldn't write a review for a product that is near the end of its life. However, I think many of the reviews and ratings of this product don't give it fair credit for its accomplishments so I've taken up the task because I am convinced that the DMC-GH1 is the best micro 4/3rds camera yet made in four key respects.1. The DXOMark tests show that the sensor in the GH1 is superior to any other sensor in any other 4/3rds or micro 4/3rds camera currently on the market. When Panasonic announced the GH1, they said that it had a very special (expensive) sensor, and the DXOMark tests show they weren't exaggerating. Although the sensor in the GH1 is smaller than the sensor in the Canon 7D, it is nearly as sensitive. Now that's an amazing accomplishment for which the GH1 should be given full credit.2. The GH1 has the best ergonomics of any 4/3rd or micro 4/3rds camera. It is not the smallest but it has the incredibly useful flip out LCD that lets you easily take pictures and movies from every possible crazy angle which no other camera in its class offers. This simple feature is extremely useful and whenever I switch to another camera that lacks it I sorely miss it. And for those times you don't want to use the articulating LCD, the GH1 has an excellent high resolution electronic view finder (EVF). No other camera in its class has both.3. The GH1 takes the best movies of any 4/3rds or micro 4/3rds camera. It offers the highest temporal (720p60) and spatial (1080p24) resolution, the least aliasing and artefacting, no recording limits, and the most most filmic look. That's beyond dispute. IMO, the movies from the GH1 are better than the movies from any other HDSLR including the Canon 5D/7D (lower measured spatial resolution, horrible aliasing, no autofocus, 12 minute limit), the Samsung NX (horrible rolling shutter), and even the just announced Sony NEX5 (horrible aliasing and line artifacts). The 1080p24 from the GH1 is not perfect, yes it has problems, but its problems are much easier to work around than the horrible aliasing from the other HDSLRs.4. The GH1 comes with an outstanding 14-140mm kit lens, that can silently and continuously autofocus in 1080p movies.So that's four very important areas in which the GH1 is the best in its class by a long shot. As far as I can tell, the GH1 falls short in only two areas: it is slightly larger than the other micro 4/3rds cameras, and not as stylish as some. I'm a big fan of pocketability, but let's be frank, no micro 4/3rds camera will fit in your pants pocket.

Reviews.Title: The future of cameras
Reviews.Author: R. daley
Reviews.Content: What makes this camera different is the ability to make both excellent still and video pictures with one (relatively) small camera. My Sony HD video camera is bulky and akward to use and my Canon digital SLR doesn't take movies. Many times I used to go to events (school plays, etc.) with the point-and-shoot just because I wanted both stills and movies and I didn't want to carry a bag o' stuff with me. Therefore, I have been waiting for this camera for a long time.I have been using this camera for a month (including the christmas/new years holidays) and I have been extremely happy with the convenience and quality of this camera. The stills and the videos are both on par with my DSLR and Digital video camera and are far above my point-and-shoot. I take videos in the 720P mode as the 1080 mode seems to have interlace artifacts (even though the sales literature says it is progressive).The big difference between this camera and a digital video camera is that you know longer have to mess around with the tapes. That means that reviewing what you recorded is much easier and less dangerous and transferring to the computer is much easier. A huge win.The big difference between this camera and a DSLR is that you are not looking through a mirror when you look through the viewer. This means that what you see is what you get. Why would ever put a mirror on a digital camera? It's ridiculous.The bottom line is that there is not a DSLR that can do all of the things this camera can do and there is not a video camera that can do all of the things this camera can do.

Reviews.Title: Best hybird in the price point

Reviews.Content: For those who argue that image isn't as good as dslr is mainly due to the kit lens that is definite below average in low light, other than that it shine most other area.The image quality can be excellent as good as DSLR, the camera definite over expose like canon dslr, you might need to adjust a bit or do post processing. the 720p avchd can produce very high quality smooth hd video that easily beat quality of those hd program. is about 14-15mb bit rate show in ps3.I original interest going for Canon 7d, but try it and felt is way too heavy for me and i am worry if drop damage might much greater. gh1 body itself isn't that cost compare to 7d.  since the lens aleady sold for $850 My friend has t1i, he was suprise that my camera outperform him in many situation not just video but image too. his camera produce far more noise pictures and video. Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Cindy Vass
Reviews.Content: We got this per some coworker's recommendation and it turned out exactly what he sold it as. It was great for what we wanted to do which was take HD videos of Antarctica marine life. Splendid! It's easy to use and there are lots and lots of functions to play around with and meet all your needs for a camera.

Reviews.Title: A Film Maker's first DSLR
Reviews.Author: Jason Walsh "thatwalshguy"
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR, and I mostly got it to record better video footage on my vacations.  So far, I've been completely satisfied with the product.  For all you film makers out there, let me just quickly note a few things for you:-The microphone port is not standard, so if you're using an external mic make sure you grab the adapter-AVCHD is very annoying to get into your editing software.  Premiere Pro CS4 has specific options for this, but many programs are fussy.  If you plan to bring your footage into after effects, you're going to get weird flickers and artifacts.Regardless, it's worth these little annoyances because the photo is so gorgeous.  Plenty of settings to alter and adjust, and the depth of field during shooting is great.  Just make sure to get big SD cards (at least class 6), because you're going to need them.

Reviews.Title: Best video dslr around (if your priority is video)
Reviews.Author: Kyle Murphey
Reviews.Content: Pros: This is a wonderful little EVIL (electronic viewfinder interchangeable lens) camera. I am a cinematography student and bought this camera specifically for it's video capabilities. Don't get me wrong it takes great pictures, but the video is as good or better than any other DSLR type camera on the market.-This camera is also HIGHLY adaptable to different lens formats. I bought a cheap $30 lens adapter now I can use all kinds of great and cheap old Canon FD lenses, which even their new EF cameras cant use.-Because of its shallow flange depth can be use just about any other camera's lenses as long as you can find an adapter.-I rented a PL adapter to use it with a set of $10k Zeiss ultra prime lenses for a film. (Something you can't do with a 7D or 5D without opening the camera up and modifying it permanently)-Shoots real 24p video, and also 60fps video, which is great for slow-mo stuff.-Achieves a nice shallow depth of field look.-Focus isn't hyper critical like with 5DCons: -Four thirds lenses are expensive-Sensor bit smaller than APS-C (which is the same size as 3 perf movie film)-Because of sensor size all lenses focal lengths are doubled in terms of FOV-No way to plug in an external monitor for live viewing anywhere other than on camera.-1080 24p video comes out as 1080 60i, which must be converted to 24p-Kit lens is slow at f4-some C-mount lenses have a little vignetting, because the sensor is a little larger than super 16 movie film.-Hard to find lenses which will be wide angle on this camera for a reasonable price.-Canon EF lenses don't have an aperture ring, so they must be used wide open on the GH1-The LCD doesn't look nearly as good as the excellent EVFOther Thoughts: -Great camera for non serious photographers, and film students-Comes with an excellent kit lens, which is highly flexible and focuses well if you need autofocus on video-I prefer the electronic view finer with focus assist over an optical one it is very high resolution, and allows for focus assist-View finder still works in live view mode (because it is always in live view mode) so you have a view finder when taking video clips (unlike 7d or 5d)

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera Loaded w/ Features
Reviews.Author: carolina2834
Reviews.Content: I recently reviewed the E-P1 a couple months ago stating it would be my last camera. Well, I lied. I started getting into video more, so I wanted a camera with full manual control and 24P at an affordable price. That narrowed it down to a 7D, T2i, or GH1. I chose the GH1 mainly due to lens compatability and size. My feelings towards the camera were a bit cold at first. I knew that it was loaded with features, but I guess the E-P1's aesthetics (and my G11) just felt "warmer" when using it. The GH1 is a bit more industrial, but now that I'm used to it, it really doesn't matter much.The main feature that separates the GH1 from many cameras, not just m43, is the high-bitrate 1080P video (after hacking). I won't get into technicalities, but I will say that most of my footage has been nothing short of amazing. I shot a little movie on backyard bugs (lame, I know) for a couple of days after receiving the camera and the footage really does look like something from National Geographic or Discovery Channel. The only gripes I have about the video is the banding at ISO's past 800. If not properly exposed, the footage is borderline unusable for full-screen viewing. It's not too bad for small-screen web viewing, but if I'm doing something presentable, 500 is probably my limit.Pictures from the GH1 are pretty nice too, but the JPEGs aren't as good as the PENs. If you're not feeling too inspired to edit each and every photo, and you simply want a great out-of-the-box JPEG machine with nice skin-tones and colors, get a PEN. You definitely will not be dissapointed. I've made prints from both the GH1 and the E-P1, and I can honestly say that prints from the E-P1 look better; to my eyes at least. However, it's a moot point if you're shooting RAW. The GH1 has better ISO sensitivity (worse banding control, however), and I wouldn't mind pushing a photo to 1600 or even 2000 since I have Dfine and can easily clean up most of the noise and banding seen at higher ISOs.While the GH1 is bigger, uglier (IMO), and less portable than the PENs, it makes up for it with better ergnomics, a swivel LCD, and a nice and bright EVF. The PEN looks better than the GH1 when displaying the two bodies next to each other, but the GH1 feels better in the hand after getting used to the aesthetics. Although the GH1 isn't substantially larger than the E-P1, the extra protrusions from the viewfinder, and grip may make it less portable for some who value size over function. It's definitely not as large as my old E-620 or E-510, but it is large enough that I'll consider leaving it at home or in the car if I don't have my messenger bag on me.Overall, I have to say that I really like the GH-1. Video is amazing, pictures are great, and as of now it's probably the best all-around camera in the m43 range. I  can't find a reason to glance at the GH2 unless if Panasonic somehow increases the AVCHD bitrates to 35-40MBps and improve FPN.If you're looking for high quality videos at an affordable price, it's hard not to recommend the GH1. If you don't care too much about 1080/24P video and can settle with 720/30P with great JPEGs, then I recommend the E-PL1 or E-P2 (E-P1 has no manual controls for video to stop strobing at high shutter speeds). In the end, I say 4.5 stars, but I'll give it 5 because of Amazon's star rating-system.

Reviews.Title: Meets My Needs Better Than Any Camera I've Ever Owned
Reviews.Author: Steven M. Frankel
Reviews.Content: As someone who has been involved with every aspect of still photography for more than 50 years, and has never gone a year without buying at least one camera, I've got to say the Lumix GH-1 is the best one I've ever used for the purposes important to me. Nearly all of the photos I take are either travel shots from the 2 international cruises we take each year (this year being a cruise along the Norwegian and Scottish coasts, and rounding Cape Horn from Santiago to Buenos Aires) or  yacht racing photos taken from a pitching race committee boat. To meet these needs, I need a camera that can:* Go from super-telephoto to wide angle in seconds (picture an 80' yacht bearing down on the committee boat at 20 knots or more at the start of a race, and only veering off when it's 5 feet away);* Produce high-quality 13"x19" enlargements suitable for framing (which in my environments usually requires effective "anti-shake" along with a sharp lens);* Have an "old fashioned" viewfinder that's effective in bright sunlight on the ocean;* Be comfortably carried, along with the main lenses you need, on a camera or wrist strap with extra lenses in your jacket pockets, on a 6-8 hour tour with lots of walking and both indoor and outdoor shooting opportunities; and* Be replaced if it's stolen or damaged without mortgaging my house.My 2008 attempt to meet these ideas was a Sony Alpha 350 with a Tamron 28-300 mm lens and a Sony f1.8 50mm lens.  It met all of the requirements except for the comfortable carry.  The camera with the Tamron super zoom was just too heavy and bulky to carry all day  -- especially in tropical settings.  My 2009 attempt was the Panasonic Lumix G-1 with the 14-45mm & 45-200mm kit lenses, and the Lumix 20mm f1.7 lens for indoor work.  This combo was much more comfortable than the Alpha outfit to carry on a walking tour but required switching lenses to go from wide angle to long telephoto -- a impossibility for many of the photo opportunities I seek.For 2010 I wanted to better satisfy these same requirements, but also begin to explore video photography in these same settings.  I selected the Lumix GH-1 with the 14-140 lens (the 35mm equivalent of 28-280mm) and high-definition video capabilities, plus the Lumix 20mm f1.7 lens I already own.  After using this combo over the Memorial Day weekend, I can honestly say it meets my needs better than any camera I've ever owned.  The GH-1 with the 14-140 zoom is compact and  weighs less than 2 pounds, and the 20mm f1.7 "pancake" lens weighs only a few ounces and can even fit in a trouser or shirt pocket.  Further, the photos are as sharp as any camera I've used that's even remotely portable and affordable, regardless of which lens I use.I have to admit that my first attempts at shooting videos were a fiasco, but I know that I'll learn the skills to do this within the next year or so.  And in the meantime I'm enjoying the GH-1 which at $1180 at Amazon was about half their cost of a G2 and the 14-140 lens; has video capabilities that are better than the G1's and most hernia-inducing Canons and Nikons with similar zooms selling for 3-4 times the cost; and can fit in a corner of my carry-on bag.  Sure I'd like full-frame capabilities in a 2-pound package with a similar zoom, as well as even better low-light capabilities, but I figure this is likely to be several years away.

Reviews.Title: Bought the gh1 when it first came out. Love it!
Reviews.Author: Audilover "KJ"
Reviews.Content: I use it for family vacations, architecture, grand kid shots, sports, wildlife. The kit lens (14-140) is amazingly competent, but I also have some fine old Canon FD lenses I use with a converter.  The video is a special treat for family events. Unqualified recommendation.

Reviews.Title: Do it all camera with potential beyond its years...
Reviews.Author: Matthias Lambert "Renaisance Dad"
Reviews.Content: I'll start with I have been shooting with this camera for 3 years off and on.  I have shot everything from portraits in a studio, street shooting, sporting events, and family functions.  The camera has never let me down and considerint it is 3 year old technology that is a true rarity.  In addition there are 3rd party firmware hacks that further improve the video and still image capabilities making superior in my opinion to many current compact system cameras.  Out of the box the kit lens Panasonic 14-140mm f/4.0-5.8 OIS Micro Four Thirds Lens for Panasonic Digital SLR Cameras has decent capabilities limited mostly by low light performance.  The battery hold a charge and allows for easy sessions of 400+ shutter fires, closer to 300 Panasonic DMW-BLB13 Battery for G10K, G1K, G2K, GF1, GF1C, GF1K, GH1K Panasonic Micro Four Thirds Cameras (Retail Packaging)if flash is used regularly.  The IQ is great surpassing many of the DSLRs that I have used and the size is so convenient when you don't want to stick out like a sore thumb.  That being said the format of the camera is still respectable enough that in professional settings your client or subject will comply accordingly.The meat of the camera revolves around the Micro four thirds mirrorless format, while 3 years ago the offerings were limitedalong the lines of both camera bodies and especially lens this has all changed recently.  The lens offerings are more than sufficient from pancake style wide angle with fast glass to primes with amazing color rendition and sharp capturing, to the ubiquitous zoom lens offering the reach out and touch them abilities of the larger DSLR offerings but let me remind you that this camera format allows you to have lenses easilly 20-30% smaller and lighter with the same zoom capabilities.  The 14-140mm lens (28-280mm equivelent in 35mm) is the size of a soda pop can.  In 35mm form it would easilly be the size of a large water bottle and probably 3/4" wider.  I could go on extensively with regard to carry ability and M4/3 size advantage the reality is it still has to take great pictures.I was new to digital when I picked this up, had gone through 3-6 point and shoot cameras and always been dissappointed in the shutter lag slow aperature and horrible low light performance.  But the thought of hauling around 10+ pounds of gear for every function was off putting, enter the Lumix G series.  The shutter lag is next to nil, and the performance otherwise is as good as your glass or lens.  My 25mm f/1.4 Leica DG Summilux Aspherical Micro 4/3 Lens and Olympus M. Zuiko Digital ED 45mm f/1.8 Lens for Micro Four Thirds Cameras are as fast and certainly as crisp as any glass I've ever used even in film days, and the equivelant 35mm legnth 50mm and 90mm make them the ideal prime lens.  I have blown up to 11x 14" with no pixelation at all and even to poster size prints with amazing clarity.  The ISO is on the average to lower side now with a reality of ISO800 being the limit for most shots before becoming grainy.  The ability for long exposures 60 sec. allows for nice composition of night shots.  The ease of the menu navigation and simple function buttons makes it a breeze to adjust to the changes of the environment and/or the changes to the image composition you are looking for.  Simple gadgets included are film modes (with a designated easy to find button) from black and white to vivid color or various degrees of smooth or high contrast settings.  The iA is also quite forgiving and in my wifes hand (who has no interest in the art of photography but rather capturing the moments as they happen and producing appealing pictures) has made some postcard quality shots and continues to impress her with how easy and fun it can be.  There are various priority modes from "aperature" "shutter" "custom" "iA" "macro" "night" all of which have nice sub menus to cater to the situation.  For those like myself that wanted to take my photography further, the control is limitless with what you can manually adjust as well allowing me to really improve my pictures and my abilities as well as learning the digital photography art more thoroghly.The video capability is way beyond mine, I have produced some effortless clips and stunning short legnth videos, but my knowledge is less than enough to accurately review its ability other than it made me look like I kneew what I was doing with the simple push of the designated video button, and easy editing on my Apple MacBook Pro MD313LL/A 13.3-Inch Laptop (NEWEST VERSION)  It is fast accurate bright and simple to produce great video in my opinion and with the firmware hack mentioned earlier this body is condidered by many to be a professional grade portable system.I'll cut this off with some bullet points:+size+battery life+image capture speed+availability of lens for all situations+ease of use+ability to maually control the camera and produce stunning images+HD video ability beyond almost all other system cameras+SD card compatibility+iA mode will make 99% of the users feel like they can take pictures with confidence+RAW and jpeg file capture for post processing and easy sharing of file in high resolution-lens expense-no in camera image stabilization (panasonic lens has IS where needed)-low light performance with kit lens 14-140mm and 14-45/42mm (overcome by additional lens purchase)-single card slot for those busier daysI highly recomend this camera still 3 years later, and for the novice or the experienced this camera will not dissappoint, being 3 years old now it is much less expensive and the lens offerings make it an even better camera than it was the day I bought it.  I recomend these lens:Panasonic LUMIX G 20mm f/1.7 Aspherical Pancake Lens for Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Cameras this is the smallest most accurate lensPanasonic Lumix 14mm f/2.5 G Aspherical Lens for Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Cameras smallest WA lens25mm f/1.4 Leica DG Summilux Aspherical Micro 4/3 Lens my favorite all around lens used 99% of my days great for all lighting situations down to darkOlympus M. Zuiko Digital ED 45mm f/1.8 Lens for Micro Four Thirds Cameras nice medium legnth prime lens with superior image qualitiesOlympus M. Zuiko Digital ED 12mm f/2.0 Lens for Micro Four Thirds Camerasgreat wide angle lens with tac sharp capture out to the edges of the image when stepped down one to two notches, and a sufficient macro shooter as well with fast aperature for such a compact size.All of these lens are still being covetted by m4/3 shooters as well so as you develop your skill or down the line decide to expand your body the lens will be with you for years or generations to come.  Many feel m4/3 and four thirds in general is a valid format to start taking market shares, like 35mm was back in the day when everybody laughed, this was the camera that really validated the format with both amazing still images and industry standard level video capture.-

Reviews.Title: If you liked film SLR's, you'll like this
Reviews.Author: M. whitton
Reviews.Content: I held off buying a DSLR for years due to the size, cost, and complications.  My past experience was with film SLR's in the 70's and 80's.  The DSLR's just seemed like big slugs with too many buttons.  MY point and shoot digital canon was just fine, thank you.I bought this unit because of its size and customer reviews.  I am extremely happy with it.  Compact enough, suitably automatic when needed, suitably manual when needed, extremely long battery life, reasonably easy controls, great picture quality.  I bought two lenses (wide to slight tele and long telephoto zoom) and both are fine and I got an adapter for my old pentax film lens set.

Reviews.Title: Good Christmas Gift
Reviews.Author: averagejane
Reviews.Content: I got this for my then boyfriend for Christmas last year.  He borrowed his friend's camera (the exact same one) for our trip to Japan and it seemed like he really enjoyed playing with it and his effort to taking good pictures seem to make him happy, so I got this for him.  I don't know if he still has it or uses it, but when we were in Japan we got some really great pictures with it.  It's much more compact and lighter than Nikon's so it's actually ideal for traveling if you're not into lugging a huge camera around.

Reviews.Title: Jack of all trades
Reviews.Author: LgT
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for a camera capable of high quality photos and also with great video capabilities, then the GH1 should be on your shopping list. It focuses reasonably fast, has more features and controls than some entry-level DSLR's, makes good-looking HD video with continuous auto-focus, and captures high quality sound. The newer GH2 is slightly better in terms of video quality and ergonomics, but I don't feel it justifies the much higher price.If you're not interested in video, then there are better options. I compared ISO1600 shots with my 4 year old Nikon D40, and the Nikon retains visibly more detail. The latest generation of DSLR's would hold an even bigger advantage.My GH1 also had the same defect mentioned by others, where the lens rotates slightly in the lens mount while zooming, and this is picked up as audible noise by the microphones. For this reason my GH1 is going back to Amazon.

Reviews.Title: The most versatile camera I have used
Reviews.Author: George
Reviews.Content: Cameras are still at a stage where size matters.  I own full frame Canon and the images are stunning but the body and lenses fill a large backpack and weigh a lot.  For an easy walking around camera I have a Canon G10 which fits in my pocket but is limited to one lens and the images, though surprisingly good in the right circumstances, are not comparable to the big camera.  The G10 is almost useless for shooting children or moving subjects.  The Lumix GH1 was designed to fit in between both functionally and in terms of size, and offer a good movie option as well.It is bigger than a point and shoot but still smaller and lighter than any regular dslr.  Easy to carry with a strap over the shoulder or in a small backpack.  The kit lens is very good and combined with an equally good 7-14 zoom offers a range from extreme wide angle to long telephoto, way beyond the capability of any point and shoot.  It focuses fast and reliably, especially when shooting children with face detection.  The stills are better than a point and shoot but not quite as good as a full frame dslr.  The colors are deeper and richer than a point and shoot but the color balance is not quite as stunning as the big Canon.  Grain and detail are very well controlled up to 800 ISO.  The movies are good quality and the sound is captured well both close and far.But there are compromises.  The size is achieved by eliminating the mirror and pentaprism of a dslr using a live electronic image instead.  This is generally useful for framing but not for detailed review of the shot beforehand.  For example, the effect of a polarizer cannot be seen through the viewfinder.  Precise manual focus is difficult or not possible.It is also difficult to shoot more than one shot quickly.  Each shot is frozen in the viewfinder for a few seconds before it returns to live view and another shot can be taken.  So the GH1 shoots one shot quicker than a point and shoot but does not allow a fast series of shots like a dslr.  This is a real limitation when shooting children or sports.The biggest challenge I have found is the color.  Canon has generally gotten color right.  Panasonic has a slightly different balance and though generally very good the prints just don't grab like the big Canon's do.  I suspect that it is partly due to the smaller sensor.  Getting the color right will likely improve with experience.  It is also easy to inadvertently hit the color balance button on the back of the camera.  Fortunately the menu is obvious in the viewfinder but you need to learn to pay attention because it disappears as soon as the shutter button is pressed.So, this is now my main travel camera, what I use to photograph my grandson when the big camera is too big to haul around, and my new movie camera.  It is well designed and generally keeps the compromises to a minimum.  Face detection and an articulating screen are a real plus.  Overall, pricy but good quality and unmatched for versatility.

Reviews.Title: Bad vertical line smear
Reviews.Author: L. Schrader
Reviews.Content: The camera I got had bad vertical lines through it's sensor image.  If you search for "GH1 vertical lines", there are many post about this.  Mine had it and my friends' had it too, we both sent them back.  Unfortunate, we both had high hopes for it's potential.  Low light, daylight, all iso settings, it was there, and it seems others have had it too.  Not trying to be negative, I even tried to, as some suggested, "burn it in", but it did not go away.  Just make sure to look closely on a big monitor.  Being a professional DP, it was a big disappointment.There was a lot to like, manual control, 3rd party features, depth of field, etc.  But there is no way to overcome a bad sensor.  I do like the Panasonic TM700, and for me it shoots great video at 1080P 60 frames per second, which has a lot of options for playback speed.  Panasonic makes some great stuff, maybe the next model will do better.  It also seems some people don't have this problem, so I guess it's a bit of a crap shoot.  I don't know, I can only speak and pass on my experience.I also found the stills quality lacking, outside of the sensor lines issue which was in stills mode also.  I do a lot of timelapse work, and even the Canon Rebel XS at $400 some dollars, is in my opinion is a far superior stills camera.  I wish I could have said how great it is, again, I had very high hopes, but for me it was a waste of time and effort.  I like and use other Panasonic products professionally (again I own two Panasonic TM700 cameras), just not this model.

Reviews.Title: Beware Lumix Cameras from Angel Seller
Reviews.Author: Peter
Reviews.Content: I purchased a Panasonic Lumix GH1K from Amazon through Angel Seller last May. I live in California and Angel Seller is in Brooklyn, NY. The camera with the 14 to 140mm zoom lens cost over $1370. It was my first experience with an HD capable camera. Its User Manual is almost 200 pages long, so there is a steep learning curve. The HD video seemed to record fine when viewed from the camera's LCD screen. I did not have time to edit my work for several months.Last month I attempted to create a DVD using Final Cut Pro & DVD Studio Pro software. DVD Studio Pro balked because the files were PAL rather than NTSC (American standard.) I called Panasonic Tech support and ascertained that I had been sold the European version of the Lumix GHI. Moreover, the HD records at 25P and 50P rather than 30P and 60P (the codecs used on this side of the Atlantic.) My HD movies had frame drops and other miscues as a result. The Panasonic Techs informed me the issue was built into the camera and could not be fixed with software or firmware.I then found that there was no way to contact Angel Seller directly (no phone number or address) except through a message from my Amazon account. Using the Amazon account, I questioned why they had sold me a European camera when I live in California, and asked if they could exchange it for the American version. There only response was through Amazon and is quoted in full: "We're sorry. More than 90 days have passed since you placed this order from Angel Seller."The Lumix GH1 is a well designed, excellent camera, but mine is worthless for video purposes in the USA. HD video really is the reason why I bought this camera. I already have an excellent Nikon D40x for still photography. I feel blind-sided and really burned, and I question Angel Seller's integrity in the matter. How do they get off selling PAL cameras to NTSC customers? I would have rated them with zero stars if that was possible.Watch out if you do business with this dealer. They obviously do not want to hear back from their customers. It will cost me dearly to replace this GH1.

Reviews.Title: Camera Defective after 2 weeks of use
Reviews.Author: J. Janca
Reviews.Content: First, I will be fair to the GH1 camera.  Coming from a 1DSMKIII and 5D, the little GH1 was easy to get used to design-wise, and I felt the quality of the pictures were very good at lower ISOs.  The kit lens actually looks sharper at wider focal lengths then my Canon 24-70 2.8 L, though the tele side is pretty soft.  You can carry this thing around and not even feel it.  But it is not built like a professional camera, even a semi-pro one.  I've owned mine for 1 day shy of two weeks and already the i-bolt (don't know the real name) that is physically attached to cameras side where the camera strap is supposed to connect to popped off.  This is a major problem as it happened while the camera was around my neck.  Luckily I felt the camera slip and was able to catch it before it fell.  Others might be less fortunate if this problem turns out to be a design or manufacturing defect because in addition to the potential for the camera to drop off your neck at any moment, the connector that attaches to the i-bolt inside the camera is now off floating around inside the body somewhere... if its metal and it connects  with a circuit board this could get ugly.I hope this does not happen to anyone else.**Update**As of Nov. 2nd I have received a full-refund for this problem, though it took a lot longer than it should have.  I updated my star rating to reflect that.

Reviews.Title: Image Quality Not Good
Reviews.Author: Moe Greene
Reviews.Content: Everything about this camera spec-wise is very attractive.  I really like the size, the range of the lens, the versatility of the video, etc., but when it came right down to it, the image quality and performance of the camera/lens combo for still images was pretty bad, especialy indoors.  First, the lens is quite slow.  Combine this with a very weak flash, and you have a lot of trouble getting a properly exposed picture indoors.  Wehn you use auto ISO, the camera stubbornly keeps the ISO at 100.  The camera always selects a slow shutter speed (1/30 or 1/40) instead of upping the ISO.  If you are content to use all manual settings, it is posible to get a well-exposed indoor shot, but with the auto modes, forget about it.  Outdoors the image quality is pretty good, but nowhere near the quality from a standard sized DSLR like a D90.So after using the camera for a couple weeks, I sold it.  Even thought the D90 is considerably bigger, the small size of the GH1 is not worth the trade-offs to me.
